lines.text: And what is your age?
[smiling, nervous and not speaking for several seconds]
Did you not hear the question that I asked?
I heard your question. I could not believe that you asked it.
Don't you want the jury to know how old you are?
I cannot think that it is any of their business. I don't know their ages, why should they know mine?
[continuing smiling while people in the courtroom chuckle]
Silence!
Ah, so you won't say in what year you were born then?
I was born in the year of my birth.
I assure you, it's quite customary to tell one's age in the witness box.
And I assure you it is quite incompatable with the civilized behavoir. No gentleman would dream about insisting upon it.
I'm sure my learned opponent would agree with you whole-heartedly. How he would like us to believe that all suck things such as birth certificates, eh, should be ignored or even surpressed.
Neither in my case. Merely lost.
How lost? In a fire?
In a fire, exactly.
And what fire was that, Mrs. Medicott?
Any fire you like.
Are you dining at home?
Yes, Alice expects me. Here, um, will you come too? Are you free?
My dear boy, I am freedom's prisoner.
